question: Which aircraft are given landing priority?

choices.choice: An aircraft with VVIP on board
An aircraft with critical shortage of fuel
A scheduled aircraft

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Priority Rules. The following general rules, as detailed below, shall apply in determining the order of priority of aircraft operations:

a) An aircraft which is known or believed to be in emergency compelling it to land without delay; e.g. aircraft experiencing engine failure, acute shortage of fuel or total communication failure.

b) Military fighter flights invariably experience shortage of fuel if not allowed to proceed as per the planned operations. Any alteration to their optimum flight profile (flight path/level) should be avoided / minimized in general. The ground time limitations of military fighter aircraft entail that the departures are accommodated from intended Civil/Military aerodromes without any delay.

c) An aircraft engaged in a live scramble.

d) An aircraft carrying sick or injured persons, requiring urgent medical attention or carrying out approved medical evacuation (Medical Flights).

e) An aircraft carrying VVIP as laid down in procedures for their handling.

f) An aircraft proceeding on Search and Rescue missions.

g) Military flight carrying out large integrated formations in military exercises.

h) Aircraft / RPA in approved urgent operational military commitment which been coordinated with appropriate ATC Centres.

i) Aircraft on large scale weather deviations.

j) Aircraft landing at alternate aerodromes after diversion due adverse opera ‘ or weather conditions at their intended destination.

question: An Aircraft shall report

choices.choice: 8NMs
4NMs
1NMs

subject: Regulations
explanation:
The report “FINAL” is required less than 7 km (4 NM) from touchdown. The report “LONG FINAL” is made when aircraft turn on to final approach at a distance greater than 7 km (4 NM) from touchdown or when an aircraft on a straight-in approach is 15 km (8 NM) from touchdown.

question: What is defined as aerodrome movement area?

choices.choice: Area including runways / taxiways excluding apron
Area excluding taxiways but including runways and apron
Area including runway / taxiways / aprons

subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Movement Area: This refers to the part of an aerodrome used for the take-off, landing, and taxiing of aircraft.
  • It includes:
    • The manoeuvring area (runways and taxiways).
    • The apron(s) where aircraft are parked, loaded, and serviced.

question: Aerodrome traffic consists of what?

choices.choice: Aircraft on the movement area and flying in the vicinity.
Aircraft on the manoeuvring area and flying in the vicinity
Aircraft on the movement area only.

subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Aerodrome Traffic: Refers to all traffic operating on the manoeuvring area of an aerodrome (including taxiing, taking off, and landing aircraft) as well as all aircraft flying in the vicinity of the aerodrome.

This includes both aircraft on the ground and those in the surrounding airspace near the aerodrome

question: When ATC instructs to “hold short,” where should the pilot stop?

choices.choice: With nose gear on hold line
So that no part of the A/c extends beyond hold line
So that the Fit Deck Area of A/c is even with the hold line

subject: Regulations
explanation:
When air traffic controllers instruct pilots to “hold short of the runway,” it means

• Stop before crossing the runway and wait for further clearance.

• No part of the aircraft should extend beyond the holding position marking.

• This procedure is used to balance airport capacity and system efficiency with safety

question: Apron is defined as an area used for what activities?

choices.choice: Loading/ unloading of passengers, mail and cargo only.
Parking of aircraft only
Loading/unloading of passengers, mail and cargo, fueling, parking or maintenance.

subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Definition: An apron is a defined area on a land aerodrome (airport) specifically designed to accommodate aircraft.
  • Purpose: The apron serves multiple functions, including:
    • Loading and unloading passengers, mail, or cargo
    • Fuelling aircraft
    • Parking aircraft
    • Conducting maintenance operations

question: How many runway segments are considered for snow friction reporting?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
A runway is typically divided into three equal segments (touchdown, mid, and rollout zones) when reporting friction levels due to snow or other contaminants. These segments help assess the condition of the runway along its entire length to provide pilots with necessary information for safe landing and takeoff operations

choices.choice: Than at a runway-holding position.
Than at runway edge.
Than at 40 from the runway edge.

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Holding point. Aircraft shall be held at a designated holding point. The required minimum
\nvertical, lateral or longitudinal separation from other aircraft, according to the system in use at that holding point, shall be provided

question: For safety, people must remain at least how far away from a jet engine?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
The safe distance to avoid jet blast is generally considered to be at least 200 feet away from the aircraft. This distance is recommended by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and is based on the potential force and turbulence created by the jet blast.

question: What is the definition of a controlled aerodrome?

choices.choice: It must be located within a CTR.
It must have a control tower giving an ATC service.
It must have a control tower and be in a CTR.

subject: Regulations
explanation:
Designating an aerodrome as “controlled” means that air traffic control (ATC) service is provided at that aerodrome. All traffic is subject to ATC clearance, regardless of flight rules.

\n
